The most important observation is that this inhomogeneous equation is related to the homogeneous linear equation x+y=0x + y = 0x+y=0. Let the vector space of solutions to this equation be VVV. Any homogeneous solution [a,b]∈V[a, b] \in V[a,b]∈V can be added to [1,1][1, 1][1,1] to get another solution to x+y=2x + y = 2x+y=2! That is, a+1+b+1=(a+b)+(1+1)=0+2=2a + 1 + b + 1 = (a + b) + (1 + 1) = 0 + 2 = 2a+1+b+1=(a+b)+(1+1)=0+2=2. Here we see why homogeneous linear equations are important: we can always translate by a homogeneous solution to x+y=0x + y = 0x+y=0 without changing the value of x+yx + yx+y.

Therefore, we can describe all the solutions to x+y=2x + y = 2x+y=2 by simply saying [x,y]=[1,1]+V[x, y] = [1, 1] + V[x,y]=[1,1]+V. What does this mean? We mean that we start at [1,1][1, 1][1,1] (some particular solution), and then translate by any solution in VVV. Since the solution to the homogeneous equation is [x,y]∈V=span⁡([1,−1])[x, y] \in V = \operatorname{span}([1, -1])[x,y]∈V=span([1,−1]), another way to write it is: x+y=2  ⟺  [x,y]=[1,1]+q[1,−1] for some q∈Q x + y = 2 \iff [x, y] = [1, 1] + q[1, -1] \text{ for some }q \in\mathbf{Q} x+y=2⟺[x,y]=[1,1]+q[1,−1] for some q∈Q

Exercise 29: Solutions to an Inhomogeneous Linear Equation

Find all rational solutions to 32x+23y+12z=2\frac{3}{2}x + \frac{2}{3}y + \frac{1}{2}z = 223​x+32​y+21​z=2. Hint: answer should include a span of 222 vectors not in the same or opposite direction

Solution

First we will solve the homogeneous linear equation 32x+23y+12z=0\frac{3}{2}x + \frac{2}{3}y + \frac{1}{2}z = 023​x+32​y+21​z=0. We expect two directions of freedom, because there are three variables. So we can make two different assumptions to get vectors which are guaranteed to not be in the same direction.

An example of some convenient assumptions (to simplify the math) are: x=0x = 0x=0, y=3y = 3y=3 and x=2x = 2x=2, y=0y = 0y=0. Under the first assumption, we have 12z=−2\frac{1}{2}z = -221​z=−2, so z=−4z = -4z=−4. Under the second assumption, we have 12z=−3\frac{1}{2}z = -321​z=−3, so z=−6z = -6z=−6. Hence the two different non-zero solutions we get are:

  • [x,y,z]=[0,3,−4][x, y, z] = [0, 3, -4][x,y,z]=[0,3,−4]

  • [x,y,z]=[2,0,−6][x, y, z] = [2, 0, -6][x,y,z]=[2,0,−6]

Hence, the vector space of solutions to this inhomogeneous linear equation is V=span⁡([0,3,−4],[2,0,−6]) V = \operatorname{span}([0, 3, -4], [2, 0, -6]) V=span([0,3,−4],[2,0,−6])

The next step is to find a particular solution to the inhomogeneous equation 32x+23y+12z=2\frac{3}{2}x + \frac{2}{3}y + \frac{1}{2}z = 223​x+32​y+21​z=2. Once again, there are infinitely many of these, so we will make an assumption that simplifies the math. Let x=0x = 0x=0 and y=0y = 0y=0. Then z=4z = 4z=4 is the only solution. So [0,0,4][0, 0, 4][0,0,4] is a particular solution.

Hence, the general solution is: 32x+23y+12z=2  ⟺  [x,y,z]=[0,0,4]+p[0,3,−4]+q[2,0,−6] for some p∈Q,q∈Q \frac{3}{2}x + \frac{2}{3}y + \frac{1}{2}z = 2 \iff [x, y, z] = [0, 0, 4] + p[0, 3, -4] + q[2, 0, -6]\text{ for some }p\in\mathbf{Q}, q\in\mathbf{Q} 23​x+32​y+21​z=2⟺[x,y,z]=[0,0,4]+p[0,3,−4]+q[2,0,−6] for some p∈Q,q∈Q

Relationship to Systems of Equations

TK

Sums

Adding things is a very important part of mathematics. When we have a large number of things to add, it helps to use algebra to simplify the problem. The notation for finite sums is ∑k=1nak \sum_{k = 1}^n a_k k=1∑n​ak​ where a1,a2,…,ana_1, a_2, \dots, a_na1​,a2​,…,an​ represent some numbers. Such a sum is called a series, but we will use this term with caution, as it is often used to denote infinite sums, which we will not cover. The numbers themselves, (a1,a2,…an)(a_1, a_2, \dots a_n)(a1​,a2​,…an​), form an nnn-tuple.

Arithmetic Series

The first kind of series is a called an arithmetic series, in which the nnn-tuple satisfies the property that all consecutive pairwise differences are equal. That is, if for all 1≤k<n1 \le k < n1≤k<n, we have ak+1−ak=c a_{k+1} - a_k = c ak+1​−ak​=c where ccc is a constant, then we say that (a1,a2,…,an)(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n)(a1​,a2​,…,an​) is in arithmetic progression.

The sum of an arithmetic series can be computed by using the method of averages. The idea here is quite simple: in any arithmetic progression, the average term is a1+an2\frac{a_1 + a_n}{2}2a1​+an​​. There is a simple proof of this fact, but it is not too hard to think of intuitively. A result fundamental to statistics tells us that, letting μ\muμ represent the average of the terms, and sss their sum, s=nμ s = n \mu s=nμ

Hence, the formula for the sum of an arithmetic series is ∑k=1nak=n2(a1+an) \sum_{k=1}^n a_k = \frac{n}{2} (a_1 + a_n) k=1∑n​ak​=2n​(a1​+an​)

Geometric Series

The second kind of series is called a geometric series, in which the nnn-tuple satisfies the property that all consecutive pairwise ratios are equal. This is, if for all 1≤k<n1 \le k < n1≤k<n, we have ak+1ak=r \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} = r ak​ak+1​​=r where rrr is again a constant, then we say that (a1,a2,…,an)(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n)(a1​,a2​,…,an​) is in geometric progression.

The sum of a geometric series can be computed by polynomial multiplication. First, let α=a1\alpha = a_1α=a1​. Then we rewrite the series: ∑k=1nan=∑k=1nαrk−1=α∑k=1nrk−1=α(1+r+r2+r3+⋯+rn−1)=α(1+r+r2+r3+⋯+rn−1)(1−r)1−r=α1−rn1−r \begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^n a_n &= \sum_{k=1}^n \alpha r^{k-1} \\ &= \alpha \sum_{k=1}^n r^{k-1} \\ &= \alpha (1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots + r^{n-1}) \\ &= \alpha \frac{(1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots + r^{n-1})(1-r)}{1-r} \\ &= \alpha \frac{1-r^n}{1-r} \end{aligned} k=1∑n​an​​=k=1∑n​αrk−1=αk=1∑n​rk−1=α(1+r+r2+r3+⋯+rn−1)=α1−r(1+r+r2+r3+⋯+rn−1)(1−r)​=α1−r1−rn​​ which leads us to the formula for the sum of a geometric series with common ratio rrr, ∑k=1nan=a11−rn1−r \sum_{k=1}^n a_n = a_1 \frac{1 - r^n}{1 - r} k=1∑n​an​=a1​1−r1−rn​

Complex Numbers

Various forms of numbers arise from the desire to solve algebraic equations. This desire was originally not to be able to solve equations that have no solution, but rather to solve equations that do have a solution, but whose solution can be arrived at easier by introducing a new kind of number.

Operations

Associativity

Call an operation ■\blacksquare■ “associative” if we have for all aaa, bbb, and ccc: (a■b)■c=a■(b■c)(a \blacksquare b) \blacksquare c = a \blacksquare (b \blacksquare c)(a■b)■c=a■(b■c). We are familiar with using this rule for the +++ and ×\times× operations, on integers, rational numbers, real numbers, and complex numbers.

Exercise N: Is It Associative?

  1. Is −-− associative on real numbers?

  2. Let x^y=xyx \hat{} y = x^yx^y=xy be the exponetiation operation. Is ^\hat{}^ associative on real numbers?

  3. Consider the set of strings (sequences of letters). Let the concatenation of two strings sss and ttt be the string s∗ts*ts∗t that we get by sticking the strings together. For example, "cat" * "nip" = "catnip". Is concatenation associative?

Solution

  1. No. For example, 2−(1−1)=2≠0=(2−1)−12 - (1 - 1) = 2 \ne 0 = (2 - 1) - 12−(1−1)=2​=0=(2−1)−1.

  2. No. For example, 2^(1^2)=2^1=2≠4=2^2=(2^1)^22 \hat{} (1 \hat{} 2) = 2 \hat{} 1 = 2 \ne 4 = 2 \hat{} 2 = (2 \hat{} 1) \hat{} 22^(1^2)=2^1=2​=4=2^2=(2^1)^2.

  3. Yes, it is. It doesn’t matter the order that we combine the strings together, as long as their positions are not rearranged.

Commutativity

Call an operation ■\blacksquare■ “commutative” if we have for all aaa and bbb: a■b=b■aa \blacksquare b = b \blacksquare aa■b=b■a. We are again familiar with using this rule for the +++ and ×\times× operations, on integers, rational numbers, real numbers, and complex numbers.

Exercise N: Is It Commutative?

  1. Is −-− commutative on real numbers?

  2. Let x^y=xyx \hat{} y = x^yx^y=xy be the exponetiation operation. Is ^\hat{}^ commutative on real numbers?

  3. Is concatenation commutative on the set of strings?

Solution

  1. No. For example, 1−0=1≠−1=0−11 - 0 = 1 \ne -1 = 0 - 11−0=1​=−1=0−1.

  2. No. For example, 2^1=2≠1=1^22 \hat{} 1 = 2 \ne 1 = 1 \hat{} 22^1=2​=1=1^2.

  3. No. For example, "over" * "sleep" ≠ "sleep" * "over".
